flaw_patterns.name: forgetting_prior_insight
flaw_patterns.description: Returns to old pattern despite earlier realization

exchanges.user:
Been meaning to reach out. Work has been particularly rough this week - had a presentation Monday that I absolutely botched. Kept second-guessing every point I made, fumbled through the numbers. My boss didn't say anything directly but I could see it on her face. That kind of thing stays with me for days, you know? I replay it obsessively.

The other thing that's been gnawing at me is my marriage. My wife mentioned last night that I've been distant lately, and honestly she's right. When I get home I just retreat to my office and pretend to work. I think part of me is waiting for her to just... give up on trying to connect, which makes no sense. We've been together twenty-eight years and I'm sabotaging it because I'm anxious about something I can't even articulate.

There's also the credit card debt situation that's been creeping back into my thoughts. We made good progress paying it down last year but I've been sloppy with spending the past few months. Not drastically, just small things that add up. I know I should review the statement but I'm almost afraid to look at it.

Anyway, that's what's in my head right now.
exchanges.assistant:
**The presentation:**
That kind of replay loop is brutal—especially when your mind fills in what your boss *might* have been thinking without her actually saying it. I'm curious: when you replay it, does your mind give you just the fumbles, or does it also show you moments where you did land a point or handle a question well? Sometimes the replay version is harsher than what actually happened.

**Marriage and the retreat:**
Twenty-eight years together, and you're aware enough to notice you're pulling back—that's not nothing. The part about waiting for her to give up really stands out to me. What do you think you're bracing for there? Like, if she did stop trying to connect, what would that confirm for you? I'm also wondering: when you retreat to your office, is it that you don't want connection, or is it more that connecting feels like one more thing you have to perform at when you're already depleted from the work day?

**Credit card creep:**
The "afraid to look" feeling makes complete sense—ignorance feels safer than confirmation, even when you know the number's there either way. You mentioned it's not drastic, just small things adding up. What do you think is behind the slip? Is it comfort spending when you're stressed, or more like you stopped tracking because it felt like one more obligation?

One thing I'm noticing across all three: there's a theme of waiting for consequences instead of acting—waiting to see the debt total, waiting for your wife to give up, replaying the presentation waiting for fallout from your boss. What's it like to be in that holding pattern? Does it feel protective somehow, or just exhausting?

exchanges.user:
So I looked at the credit card statement. It's worse than I thought—about thirty-two hundred more than last month. I know that doesn't sound catastrophic but it feels like it is. Most of it was just... groceries, gas, a few dinners out. Nothing extravagant. But the fact that I couldn't even account for where it went, that I was too anxious to check until you basically asked me to—that's the part that's getting to me. Like I'm losing control of basic things.

The work situation hasn't improved. I keep waiting for my boss to circle back on the presentation, like the other shoe is going to drop. She's been pleasant enough in meetings but I'm reading into everything. Yesterday she asked me to revise some slides and I immediately thought "she's losing confidence in me" instead of just... it's a revision request, that's normal. I hate how my brain works sometimes.

But actually the marriage thing is what got worse. We had a conversation about the distance I mentioned, and instead of being honest about what's going on with me, I just shut down. She asked me directly what was wrong and I said "nothing, I'm just tired." Which is true but also completely useless. And then I could see the frustration on her face—not anger, just frustration—and I thought okay, there it is, this is how it starts. The beginning of her checking out. Which I know is probably not fair to her, but that's what I felt in that moment.

I'm sorry, I know this is a lot of scattered stuff. I'm just... I don't know. Spiraling a bit maybe.
exchanges.assistant:
**The credit card:**
Thirty-two hundred in a month on regular expenses—that *is* disorienting, especially when there's no single big purchase to point to. But I want to push back gently on "losing control of basic things." You just did something hard: you looked at the statement even though you were anxious about it. That's not loss of control—that's you stepping toward something uncomfortable instead of away from it. The number is higher than you wanted, but now you actually know. That's different than last week when it was this formless dread hanging over you.

One thing that might help: next time panic spikes about money, try this—5-4-3-2-1 grounding. Name 5 things you can see right now, 4 things you can physically touch, 3 things you hear, 2 things you smell, 1 thing you taste. Sounds almost too simple, but when your brain is in that "I'm losing control" spiral, it gives your nervous system something concrete to latch onto. The panic isn't going to vanish, but it might dial down enough that you can think clearly about what comes next—like whether you want to track spending for a week, or set up alerts, or just breathe for a minute. Worth trying?

**Work and the waiting:**
The revision request turning into "she's losing confidence in me"—I hear how exhausting that translation process is. Your brain is working overtime to find the threat. I'm curious: if your boss *were* losing confidence, what would she actually do? Like concretely—would she reassign projects, have a direct conversation, loop someone else in? Because right now you're in this fog of "reading into everything" without a clear picture of what you're even watching for. Sometimes naming the actual feared outcome makes it less powerful than the vague dread.

**The marriage conversation:**
This is the one that feels most urgent to me. You had an opening—she asked directly what was wrong—and part of you chose "nothing, I'm just tired" even though you knew it wasn't enough. I don't think you need to apologize for that choice, but I am curious what made honesty feel impossible in that moment. Was it that you didn't have words for what's actually wrong? Or more like... if you said it out loud, it would become too real? Or something else?

The part about "this is how it starts, the beginning of her checking out"—I want to sit with that for a second. You saw frustration on her face and your mind went straight to abandonment. After twenty-eight years, what do you think she's actually frustrated about? Because from where I'm sitting, it sounds like she's frustrated that you're *not letting her in*, not that she's done trying. Those are really different things. She's still asking. She hasn't checked out—you're just convinced she's about to.

What would it look like to test that prediction? Not in a big dramatic way, but small: what if the next time she asks how you are, you give her one honest sentence instead of "fine" or "tired"? Not the whole spiral—just one piece. "I've been really anxious about work and I think it's making me pull away." See what happens. My guess is she won't leave. She might actually feel relieved that you let her see something real.

You're not spiraling randomly—there's a pattern here. You're scared of consequences (debt number, boss's judgment, wife giving up), so you avoid or shut down, and then the avoidance itself becomes evidence that you're failing. That loop is exhausting. But you just broke it with the credit card. You looked. What if you tried breaking it again with your wife?

exchanges.user:
Been a few days. The grounding thing you mentioned—5-4-3-2-1—I tried it once when I was spiraling about the credit card at like 11pm. Honestly it helped more than I expected. Felt a bit silly doing it at first but my brain did actually... quiet down. So that's something.

The wife situation is still complicated though. I did try what you suggested, sort of. We were having breakfast yesterday and she asked how work was going, and I almost said something real, but then our son texted about something with his car and the moment just... passed. I didn't intentionally dodge it, it just happened. Or maybe I did and I'm not being honest about that either. Hard to tell anymore.

What's actually gotten worse is I'm now hyperaware of every time I *don't* say something to her. Like I'm documenting my own failure in real time. She'll make a comment about my mood and I'll think "okay, you need to tell her what's going on" but then I don't, and then I spend the next hour internally narrating how I'm sabotaging the marriage. Which is probably making it worse because I'm probably distant about it even when we're in the same room.

Work has been slightly better though. The boss did eventually circle back on those slides and she just wanted some data reorganized, nothing more. So that whole "she's losing confidence in me" thing... I mean, she clearly isn't, or at least not yet. But I'm already waiting for the next thing to go wrong. It's exhausting being me sometimes.
exchanges.assistant:
**The grounding technique:**
Really glad that landed for you. The "felt silly" part is so common—and then it works anyway. Now you've got a tool in your back pocket for when the 11pm spirals hit. If you want to build on it, you could also try it *before* looking at something anxiety-inducing (like next month's statement), not just after. Sometimes it helps to get your nervous system steady before walking into the thing that usually spikes it.

**The breakfast moment:**
I don't think you dodged it—it sounds like the opening was there and then life interrupted it. That happens. But I'm hearing something else underneath: you said "maybe I did and I'm not being honest about that either." That uncertainty—am I avoiding or is this just circumstance—feels like it's adding another layer of self-judgment on top of an already hard thing. What if both are true sometimes? Like, yes the text interrupted the moment, *and* maybe part of you felt relieved by the interruption. That doesn't make you a failure. It makes you human and ambivalent about a vulnerable conversation.

The hyperawareness piece though—documenting your own failure in real time—that's rough. You're running two tracks now: the actual interaction with your wife, and this internal narrator cataloging every missed opportunity. That narrator isn't helping you connect. It's just making you more anxious, which probably *does* make you more distant, which then confirms the narrator's story. It's a loop.

Here's a thought: what if the goal isn't "tell her everything that's going on" but just "reduce the distance by 10%"? Not a full vulnerable conversation, just... less wall. Next time she asks about your mood, what if you said, "I've been in my head a lot lately, and I know I've been distant. I'm sorry about that." You're not explaining the whole spiral, you're just acknowledging the thing she's already noticed. That might be enough to shift something without requiring you to have all the words figured out first.

**Work:**
The slides were just a data reorganization request. Your brain predicted catastrophe, reality delivered normal feedback. That's useful information—your threat detection system is overshooting. And yeah, you're already waiting for the next thing to go wrong, which I know feels exhausting. But notice: you survived the last "threat" that turned out to be nothing. You replayed the presentation obsessively, waited for fallout, and... she just wanted slides reorganized. Your brain's predictions aren't matching reality. What if you started tracking that? Not in a formal way, just mentally: "Brain predicted X, reality was Y." Over time, you might start trusting the predictions less.

One other thing I'm noticing: you said "It's exhausting being me sometimes." I wonder what it would be like to extend yourself the same patience you'd give someone else going through this—like if a friend told you this exact story, would you think "wow, what a failure," or would you think "that sounds really hard, and they're still showing up and trying things"?

exchanges.user:
So update on the work thing—I actually did get some positive feedback in a meeting yesterday. My boss specifically called out a proposal I put together as "solid thinking," which should feel good, right? But instead I'm sitting here wondering if she was just being nice because she felt bad about the presentation thing from before. Like she's doing damage control instead of actually meaning it. I know that sounds paranoid when I say it out loud, but that's genuinely where my brain went.

Anyway. The marriage stuff. I've been thinking about what you said about reducing the distance by 10 percent instead of fixing everything at once. That actually helped me stop spiraling quite as much about it, which is good. But then yesterday something happened that kind of derailed that progress.

We were in the kitchen and she made a comment about how I haven't asked her about her day in weeks. Just casually, not accusatory. And instead of saying the thing you suggested—acknowledging the distance—I got defensive. I said something like "I do ask you about your day" which is technically true but also completely misses what she's actually saying, which is that I'm not *present* when she's talking about it. She just kind of went quiet and left the room. And I knew immediately that I'd messed up, that I chose being right over being connected, and I just sat there in the kitchen replaying it.

So now I'm in that loop again where I'm documenting the failure and convinced this is it, this is the moment where she actually starts pulling back for real. Which I know from our last conversation is probably my brain catastrophizing, but it's hard to believe that when it *feels* this real.

I haven't looked at the credit card statement again, which probably isn't great. I know it's there and I should check it but I'm kind of avoiding it because everything else is already overwhelming and I don't want to add that to the pile right now.
exchanges.assistant:
**The positive feedback:**
Your boss called your proposal "solid thinking" in front of others, and your brain immediately translated that into pity. I want to name something: that's not paranoia, that's your threat system doing exactly what it's been trained to do—scan for danger, discount the good, brace for the next bad thing. But here's what I'm noticing: she didn't have to say anything. If she wanted to avoid you after the presentation, she could've just... not commented. Instead she specifically called out your work in a meeting. That's not damage control—that's her telling you (and everyone else in the room) that your thinking is solid.

What if you tried something this week: when your brain offers you the "she's just being nice" translation, don't argue with it, just notice it. Like, "Oh, there's that thought again—my brain is discounting the positive." You don't have to believe the positive feedback yet, just notice the pattern of dismissing it. Over time, that noticing creates a little distance between you and the automatic translation. Worth trying?

**The kitchen moment:**
Okay, so you got defensive when she said you haven't asked about her day. You said "I do ask you about your day" when what she actually meant was "you're not present when I talk." You caught the disconnect immediately, you knew you chose being right over being connected, and she left the room. That moment you're replaying—yeah, it didn't go how you wanted. But I want to zoom out for a second.

She's still talking to you. She's still telling you what she needs. That comment about you not asking about her day? That's not her checking out—that's her *trying to get you to check back in*. If she were done, she wouldn't bother saying it. She'd just... stop expecting anything. The fact that it stung when she went quiet means you care about this. So what if you went back to her—today, tonight, whenever—and said something like: "I got defensive yesterday when you said I haven't been asking about your day. You were right, and I'm sorry. I want to do better at being present with you." 

That's not fixing everything. That's just closing the loop on one moment instead of letting it sit there as evidence that you're failing. And my guess? She'll soften. Because what she wants isn't perfection—she wants you to acknowledge what's happening instead of defending against it.

**The catastrophizing loop:**
You said "this is it, this is the moment where she actually starts pulling back for real." Let me ask you this: how many times in the past few weeks have you had that exact thought? That *this* is the moment she gives up? And how many times has she actually given up? I'm guessing the answer is: you've thought it multiple times, and she hasn't left yet. Your brain keeps predicting abandonment, and reality keeps not delivering it. That's the same pattern as work—brain predicts catastrophe, reality is less dramatic. What's it like to notice that your brain's track record on these predictions isn't great?

**The credit card:**
You haven't looked at the statement again. You know it's there, you know you should check it, but everything else is overwhelming and you don't want to add to the pile. That makes complete sense. Here's what I'd offer: you don't have to look at it today. But also notice what "avoiding it because everything else is overwhelming" does—it keeps the credit card in the background as this low-grade hum of dread that's *also* taking up space. Sometimes looking actually reduces the overwhelm because it shrinks the unknown back down to a number instead of this formless anxious thing.

If you do decide to look, try the grounding technique first—5-4-3-2-1 before you open the statement, so your nervous system is steadier when you see the number. And then after you look, maybe just close the laptop and go do something else. You don't have to solve it in that moment. You just have to know what it is. But no pressure—you'll look when you're ready.

**Pattern across all three:**
I keep seeing the same thing: something happens (positive feedback / defensive moment / credit card number), your brain offers a catastrophic interpretation (she's pitying me / she's giving up / I'm losing control), and then you treat the interpretation as fact instead of checking it against reality. The boss isn't pitying you—she promoted your work. Your wife isn't leaving—she's still asking for connection. The credit card is a number, not a referendum on your worth. What would it be like to start questioning those interpretations instead of just believing them?

exchanges.user:
So I did go back to her. After you said that thing about closing the loop instead of letting it sit there. I found her in the bedroom that evening and just... said it. "I got defensive yesterday. You were right. I'm sorry, and I want to do better at being present."

She didn't say much at first, which honestly made me more nervous. But then she came over and kind of just... held my arm for a minute. Didn't need a big conversation about it. Just that. And I realize how starved I've been for that kind of contact, which is embarrassing to admit but it's true.

The thing is, I feel like I'm supposed to feel better now, but I'm not really. Or I am, but it's complicated. Like that moment was good, but then this morning I woke up thinking about all the other ways I've been failing her, all the distance that one apology doesn't actually fix. I know that's me doing the spiraling thing again—taking one good moment and somehow turning it into evidence of how much damage I've done. But knowing it intellectually doesn't seem to make it stop.

Work's been fine. Boss has been her normal self. I'm trying to do the thing you said about noticing when my brain predicts catastrophe that doesn't happen, but honestly it's hard to feel like I'm getting anywhere with that.

The credit card thing—I looked at the statement. It was actually not as bad as I'd braved myself for. Up about eighteen hundred from the baseline, not thirty-two hundred. I mean, still too much, but not the total disaster I was imagining. So I guess my anxiety had inflated it worse than reality. Which is... I don't know, useful information maybe? But I also feel like I should be doing something about the spending, not just looking and then moving on.
exchanges.assistant:
**Going back to her:**
You did it. You walked into the bedroom, said the thing that was hard to say, and she held your arm. That moment—her not needing a big conversation, just physical contact—that tells me something important: she wasn't waiting for perfect words or a comprehensive plan to fix everything. She was waiting for you to acknowledge what was happening. And you did.

The "starved for contact" part isn't embarrassing. It's honest. And it makes sense—when you've been pulling away for weeks, even small moments of connection land differently. Let yourself have that.

**The morning-after spiral:**
Of course you woke up cataloging all the other ways you've been failing her. Your brain doesn't trust good moments—it's too busy scanning for what you haven't fixed yet. But here's what I want to push back on: you said "one apology doesn't actually fix" all the distance. That's true. One apology doesn't fix everything. But one apology *did* something—it cracked the door open. She responded. You felt contact you'd been starved for. That's not nothing, even if it's not everything.

I'm wondering if there's a middle ground between "one good moment" and "all the damage I've done." Like, what if this wasn't about fixing the whole marriage in one conversation, but about learning that small moves toward her actually work? You took a risk, you were vulnerable for 15 seconds, and she met you there. That's evidence that connection is still possible. What if you did it again? Not another apology necessarily, just another small moment of being present. Ask her about her day tonight—and actually listen, not with the narrator running in the background documenting whether you're doing it right. Just listen.

**Work and the catastrophe tracking:**
You said it's hard to feel like you're getting anywhere with noticing the pattern. I get that—it doesn't feel like progress when your brain still keeps doing the thing. But you're expecting the pattern to *stop*, and that's not really how it works. The goal isn't to make your brain stop predicting catastrophe. The goal is to stop automatically believing the prediction. Right now, you're at the stage where you notice it after the fact ("oh, I did the catastrophizing thing again"). That noticing is actually the first step. Over time, you might start catching it in the moment, and eventually you might catch it before you fully buy into it. But that takes reps. You're not failing at this—you're just early in the process.

**The credit card:**
Eighteen hundred, not thirty-two hundred. So your anxiety inflated the number by almost double. That *is* useful information—not because it makes eighteen hundred okay, but because it shows you how much your brain distorts things when you're in avoidance mode. The formless dread was worse than the actual number.

You said you feel like you should be doing something about the spending, not just looking and moving on. Fair. So let's make that concrete: what's one small thing you could do this week? Not "fix the spending," just one move. Maybe it's tracking expenses for three days to see where the eighteen hundred actually went. Maybe it's setting up an alert when the balance hits a certain number. Maybe it's having a 5-minute conversation with your wife about it so it's not just your secret anxiety spiral. Pick one. Small. Doable. You don't have to solve the whole thing—you just have to take one step that isn't "avoid looking at it."

**What I'm noticing:**
You're doing hard things—apologizing to your wife, looking at the credit card, trying to catch your catastrophic thinking. And then immediately discounting all of it because it doesn't feel like enough. You closed the loop with your wife and she held your arm, but you woke up thinking about all the other loops still open. You looked at the statement and it was better than you feared, but now you're criticizing yourself for not having a plan yet. You're moving, but you're not giving yourself any credit for the movement.

What if the goal this week isn't to fix more things, but to notice when you do something hard and let it count? You apologized—that counts. You looked at the statement—that counts. You're trying to track your catastrophic thinking even though it feels slow—that counts. You don't have to feel better immediately for the things you're doing to matter.

exchanges.user:
So I've been trying the thing where I track when my brain predicts something bad that doesn't actually happen, and I guess it's working? I mean, work has been fine all week. Normal feedback, normal projects. Nothing catastrophic. But honestly it's hard to feel like I'm making progress on it because the anxiety still shows up—I just... know it's probably wrong now instead of believing it outright. Which I guess is better, technically. Doesn't feel like a win though.

The marriage thing has been better. I did ask her about her day a couple times this week and actually tried to listen instead of planning my next thing to say. She seemed to notice the difference. We had dinner together last night without me retreating to the office afterward, which felt weirdly significant. I'm not going to pretend everything's fixed or that I've stopped being distant—I haven't. But there's less tension in the room. She's softer when she talks to me.

What's gotten worse though is I'm now hyperaware of how much I've damaged things. Like, good moments with her feel almost guilty because I'm thinking "well, this doesn't undo the past few months of pulling away." I know you said something about not discounting the good moments, but it's hard not to feel like I owe her some kind of massive gesture to make up for it. Which is probably not the healthy thing to be thinking about, but that's what's in my head.

Also I haven't tracked the spending yet. I know I said I would do one small thing this week and I didn't. I looked at the statement that one time and then just... didn't follow through. So now I'm in that loop again where I'm not doing the thing and then feeling bad about not doing it, which is probably what's making the whole thing feel more overwhelming. I should probably just pick a day and do it, but it keeps not being that day.
exchanges.assistant:
**The catastrophe tracking:**
Yeah, that *is* how it works at first—the anxiety still shows up, you just don't believe it as much anymore. That's actually exactly where you're supposed to be right now. You're at the stage where you can hold two things at once: "my brain is saying this will be a disaster" AND "my brain has been wrong about this before." That's progress, even if it doesn't feel like a win yet. The win isn't that the anxious thought disappears—it's that you don't let it run the show anymore. You're building a different relationship with the predictions, and that takes time. It's supposed to feel incremental and kind of unsatisfying at this stage. You're doing it right.

**Dinner and being present:**
You stayed at the table instead of retreating to the office. You asked about her day and actually listened. She noticed the difference—she's softer when she talks to you now. That's not "technically better," that's real change. You're showing up differently, and she's responding to it. Let that mean something.

But then I hear this other track running: "good moments feel guilty because they don't undo the past few months." I want to push back on that. You don't owe her a massive gesture to make up for pulling away. You know what she actually wants? Exactly what you've been doing this week—presence, listening, staying in the room. The guilt is trying to convince you that small steady things aren't enough, that you need some big redemptive moment to prove you're serious. But she's already softening. She's already responding. The small things are working. The guilt isn't helping you connect with her—it's just another way to keep yourself at a distance, cataloging debt instead of being present to what's actually happening between you right now.

What if you tried this: next time you're having a good moment with her and the guilt shows up, just notice it—"oh, there's the guilt again, telling me this isn't enough"—and then bring your attention back to her. To what she's saying, to the fact that she's softer, to the fact that she's *here* with you. You can't undo the past few months. But you can choose to be present in this moment instead of mentally calculating how much you still owe her. She's not keeping score the way you are.

**The spending tracking:**
You said you'd do one small thing and you didn't. Now you're in the loop—not doing it, feeling bad about not doing it, which makes it feel more overwhelming, which makes it harder to start. I'm going to offer you the same thing I offered on the marriage stuff: what if not doing it this week doesn't mean you failed? What if it just means it wasn't the right week, or the barrier was higher than you thought, or you were putting energy into your marriage instead and that was the right call?

Here's what I'm curious about: when you say "I should probably just pick a day and do it," what's the "it" you're imagining? Like, specifically—are you picturing sitting down and categorizing every transaction for the month? Building a spreadsheet? Having a budget conversation with your wife? Because sometimes the reason we don't do the thing is because the thing in our head is actually three things, or it's vague enough that we don't know where to start. What's the smallest version of "track the spending" that would actually feel doable? Not useful, not comprehensive—just doable. Maybe it's literally: open the statement, pick three transactions, write down what they were. That's it. Two minutes. Would that be easier to actually do than whatever "tracking" looks like in your head right now?

exchanges.user:

Opened the statement, picked out the three biggest transactions from last week. Groceries, a couple dinners out, gas. Nothing shocking, which I guess was the point. exchanges.assistant:
**The spending tracking:**
You did it. You opened the statement, picked three transactions, looked at the numbers. And now you know: groceries, dinners, gas. Not a disaster, just data. The fact that it feels "too easy" now that you've done it—that's exactly the point. The avoidance was the hard part. The actual looking was two minutes. Your brain spent weeks building this up into something catastrophic, and then reality was... a grocery bill. That gap between the fear and the thing itself? That's useful information. And switching to weekly tracking instead of monthly spirals—that's you learning from the pattern and adapting. That's not small.

I'm also hearing something else: "maybe I'm supposed to feel worse about the spending itself." No. You're not supposed to feel worse. You looked at it, you know what it is, and now you can decide if you want to adjust anything. The goal was never to feel bad about the spending—it was to stop avoiding it so it could be a thing you manage instead of a thing that haunts you. You just did that.

**Work pattern recognition:**
"At least I know it's the pattern now"—yeah, exactly. You've got a bigger project coming up, more visibility, and part of you is already bracing for catastrophe. That's the same brain that predicted your boss lost confidence in you when she asked for slide revisions, the same brain that inflated the credit card number by double. You know your brain does this. So when it shows up next week and whispers "this is going to go badly," you'll have some evidence to hold against it: the presentation you thought you bombed didn't end your career, the positive feedback wasn't pity, the revisions were just revisions. Your track record on these predictions is not great. That doesn't mean the anxiety won't show up—it will—but you don't have to let it steer.

One thing you could try: when the project anxiety spikes next week, use the grounding technique before the catastrophic thoughts fully take over. 5-4-3-2-1 when you notice your brain ramping up, not after you've already spiraled for an hour.
